Q1: The fitness, health and productivity of horses should be protected by adapting their conditions and management to their biology and natural behaviour. They should be given as much access to pasture in the company of other horses as possible; stabling should be kept to an absolute minimum. No horse should be denied turnout and access to other horses. Appropriate shelter must be provided at pasture. Horses should be bred for robustness against injury as well as performance. Young should stay with the mothers for several months (at least six) and then be weaned naturally. Breeding procedures involving stress, such as use of restraints like the twitch and hobbles should not be used. Management should be planned to avoid fear and distress from birth to death, which should be humane. Training, riding and driving methods should be based upon positive reinforcement, and should not involve fear, stress or injury.

Companionship with other herd animals optimally with at least one other horse although a band size of 4-6 is premium. Mixed sex and mixed age within the band is very good. Adult and adolescent geldings mixed with adult and adolescent mares mixed with yearlings and foals is perfect. Horses need the opportunity to be and act like horses so the chance to be in open pasture with a mixed age/mixed sex band is very good for them. Standing in a stall or being in a small paddock by themselves all day will make them neurotic. They need daily exercise, the need to forage for their food so rather than giving all food in a manger it is best to scatter food around the pasture to mimic the natural foraging of wild horses. They need access to fresh clean water constantly. They need their hooves trimmed but don't always need shoes. They need activities that not only keep them physically fit and toned but provide mental stimulation as well. They need to never, ever be beat.
